Appleseed builtins¶

These functions and macros are built in to the Appleseed interpreter. All of them, unlike library functions and macros, have type Builtin.

Arithmetic¶

add¶
  • First argument: Int or Bool
  • Second argument: Int or Bool
  • Returns: Int

Adds two numbers.

sub¶
  • First argument: Int or Bool
  • Second argument: Int or Bool
  • Returns: Int

Subtracts two numbers.

mul¶
  • First argument: Int or Bool
  • Second argument: Int or Bool
  • Returns: Int

Multiplies two numbers.

div¶
  • First argument: Int or Bool
  • Second argument: Int or Bool
  • Returns: Int
  • Errors if: second argument is 0 or false

Divides two numbers. Note that this is integer division, rounding down: (div 5 3) is 1; (div -5 3) is -2.

mod¶
  • First argument: Int or Bool
  • Second argument: Int or Bool
  • Returns: Int
  • Errors if: second argument is 0 or false

Returns its first argument modulo its second. Follows the same rules as Python regarding negative arguments: the return value is constrained to be between the second argument (exclusive) and zero (inclusive). As a result, (add (mul (div a b) b) (mod a b)) is always equal to a.

Lists¶

cons¶
  • First argument: any type
  • Second argument: List
  • Returns: List

Returns a new list with the first argument as the head and the second argument as the tail.

head¶
  • Argument: List
  • Returns: any type

Returns the head (first element) of the argument, or nil if the argument is an empty list.

tail¶
  • Argument: List
  • Returns: List

Returns a new list containing the tail (all but the first element) of the argument, or nil if the argument is an empty list.

Strings¶

str¶
  • Argument: List
  • Returns: String
  • Errors if: argument contains any elements that are not Int or Bool

Given a list of character codes, returns a string consisting of those characters.

chars¶
  • Argument: String
  • Returns: List

Given a string, returns a list of its character codes (nonnegative Ints).

repr¶
  • Argument: any type
  • Returns: String

Returns a string representing the argument:

  • Int: (repr 42) → "42"
  • Bool: (repr true) → "true"
  • List: (repr (list 1 2 ())) → "(1 2 ())"
  • String: (repr "xyz") → "xyz"; (repr "xyz abc") → "`xyz abc`"
  • Object: (repr (object (type "Complex") (re 5) (im 2))) → "{(type Complex) (im 2) (re 5)}"
  • Builtin: (repr add) → "<builtin function add>"; (repr def) → "<builtin macro def>"

Booleans and conditionals¶

bool¶
  • Argument: any type
  • Returns: Bool

Returns false if the argument is 0, false, (), "", or {}. Otherwise, returns true.

if¶
  • Macro
  • First argument: any type
  • Second argument: any type
  • Third argument: any type
  • Returns: any type

Evaluates the first argument (the condition). If it is logically true (i.e. passing it to bool would return true), evaluates and returns the second argument (the true branch). Otherwise, evaluates and returns the third argument (the false branch). The branch that is not chosen is never evaluated.

less?
  • First argument: any type
  • Second argument: any type
  • Returns: Bool
  • Errors if: the two arguments’ types are not comparable (see below)

Returns true if the first argument is strictly less than the second. Types that can be compared:

  • Int or Bool can be compared against Int or Bool (with false treated as 0 and true as 1)
  • String can be compared against String (using lexicographic ordering)
  • List can be compared against List:
    • nil is less than any list but itself
    • For non-empty lists, the heads are compared first
    • If the heads are not comparable, the lists are not comparable (an error)
    • If the heads are equal, the tails are compared, continuing until the elements are inequal or one or both lists become nil
equal?
  • First argument: any type
  • Second argument: any type
  • Returns: Bool

Returns true if both arguments are of the same type and contain the same data.

Note

Infinite lists can sometimes be compared with equal?. As soon as two elements are different, the result is false, of course, but a result of true can also be returned if both lists result from identical calls to the same function. For example, (equal? (tail (0to)) (1to)) returns true: (1to) calls (count-up 1 nil), while (0to) calls (count-up 0 nil), which in turn is (cons 0 (count-up 1 nil)). Thus, both (tail (0to)) and (1to) end up as deferred calls to count-up with arguments 1 and nil, and therefore compare as equal.

However, two infinite lists that are generated in different ways cannot be compared this way, and (if they actually are equal) will result in an infinite loop. For example, (repeat-val 1) and (zip-with sub (1to) (0to)) both happen to return infinite lists of ones, but they are generated by calls to completely different functions, and so Appleseed has no way of knowing that they are equal except to check every value.

(The same reasoning holds for less?, except that it returns false when the lists are equal.)

In summary, while it does work in certain cases, it is not recommended to compare two infinite lists because of the risk of infinite loops.

Objects¶

object¶
  • Macro
  • Takes zero or more arguments
  • Each argument: two-item List
  • Returns: Object

Creates a new Object. Each argument is a name-value pair for a property of the object. The name is not evaluated, while the value is; thus, a bare name token should be used for the name, while an expression can be used for the value: (object (x (mul 6 7)))

has-property?
  • Macro
  • First argument: Object
  • Second argument: String
  • Returns: Bool

Returns true if the first argument has the property named by the second argument. The second argument is not evaluated; thus, a bare name token should be used: (has-property? (object (x (mul 6 7))) y) → false

get-property
  • Macro
  • First argument: Object
  • Second argument: String
  • (Optional) Third argument: any type
  • Returns: any type
  • Errors if: the object does not have that property and no default is provided

Looks up the property named by the second argument in the first argument and returns its value. If the object does not have the specified property but the optional third argument is supplied, returns the third argument; if no third argument is given, a missing property results in an error. The second argument is not evaluated, but the other two are.

copy¶
  • Macro
  • Takes one or more arguments
  • First argument: any type
  • Each remaining argument: two-item List
  • Returns: Object
  • Warns if: more than one argument is given but the first argument is not an Object

Returns a copy of the first argument. If the first argument is an Object, name-value pairs may be given as additional arguments, using the same syntax as in object; these properties are set in the new object, overwriting any properties of the same names from the original.

Other¶

q¶
eval¶
type¶
def¶
load¶
debug¶

REPL only¶

help¶
restart¶
quit¶
